articles.title: About me
articles.contents:
I am originally from Lima, Peru, but largely grew up in Los Angeles. I am a first generation college student and graduated cum laude at California State University, Monterey Bay with a B.S. in Environmental Science, Technology, & Policy. I am a self-motivated, fast learner and eager to apply my coding skills to the environmental management field.
Experience
During my undergraduate education I was a part of the National Science Foundation’s Research Experience for Undergraduates program. I had the opportunity to work with Dr. Steve Litvin & Dr. Jim Barry at the Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute documenting the effects of current and future climate change on abalone. I presented the results of my research at conferences such as SACNAS and the California Central Coast Chapter of The Wildlife Society’s Annual Symposium in 2018. I also volunteered with the non-profit organization Return of the Natives, where I co-taught an environmental education program for local elementary school children and assisted with community planting events aiming to restore native dune flora to the Monterey coast. Now, I am working as a research assistant for Dr. Anastasia Quintana, aiding her postdoctoral research on compliance in small-scale fisheries.
Working in the benthic ecology lab. Image: Todd WalshInterests
I love being outdoors and exploring local trails, with a particular affinity for surveying herptile communities (lizards, snakes, amphibians). My favorite undergraduate field days were the ones where I could interact with native California wildlife and learn about their ecology and relevant conservation efforts. You can always find me in the field looking for cool snakes and lizards! I previously volunteered at the UCSC Fort Ord National Reserve monitoring coastal horned lizard populations to inform the dissertation of Ph.D. candidate Danielle Davis.
Hanging out with a Monterey ensatinaAside from that, I am highly passionate about environmental justice issues and I am an avid supporter of black & indigenous rights. I hope to apply my data analysis skills to serve underprivileged groups facing environmental justice issues.
I currently reside in Goleta, CA (Chumash land) with my pet bunny and partner.
My pet bunny

            Larissa Neilson
          
          
            
              I am a first-year master’s student at the Bren School of Environmental Science & Management at UCSB, and I am pursuing a specialization in Energy & Climate. Currently, I am working as a research assistant under Dr. Anastasia Quintana, aiding her postdoctoral research at the intersection of small-scale fisheries, conservation, and collective action.
            
            
              I am a first-year master’s student at the Bren School of Environmental Science & Management at UCSB, and I am pursuing a specialization in Energy & Climate. Currently, I am working as a research assistant under Dr. Anastasia Quintana, aiding her postdoctoral research at the intersection of small-scale fisheries, conservation, and collective action.

      Larissa Neilson
      Master’s candidate
      

      
      |
       (818) 282-6200 |
      
       eneilson@bren.ucsb.edu |
      
      
      
      

      
      Education
      
      2020-2022 Master of Environmental Science and Management Bren School of Environmental Science & Management (Santa Barbara, CA)
      
      
      2015-2019 B.S. in Environmental Science California State University, Monterey Bay (Seaside, CA)
      
      
      
      Research Experience
      
      2020-present Graduate Research Assistant University of California, Santa Barbara (Santa Barbara, CA)
      
      Supervisor - Anastasia Quintana
      • Conducting literature reviews to inform postdoctoral research on compliance in small-scale fisheries
      • Identifying governance types in 75+ managed access areas throughout Indonesia, Brazil, Honduras, Micronesia, Mozambique, and the Philippines & creating a dataset with this information
      • Managing the social media presence of Dr. Anastasia Quintana to expand her network
      
      June - August 2018 Undergraduate Researcher (NSF funded) Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute (Moss Landing, CA)
      
      Supervisors - Dr. Steve Litvin, Dr. Jim Barry
      • Quantified and analyzed the effects of present & future climate change and ocean acidification associated with upwelling on juvenile red abalone through an 8-week live experiment
      • Created and maintained Excel spreadsheets with various abalone measurements from 300+ individuals
      • Conducted extensive image and statistical analysis using experimental data from 300+ individuals
      • Presented results to audiences ranging from 10-200 people at various conferences and symposiums including SACNAS and the California Central Coast Chapter of The Wildlife Society’s Annual Symposium (2018)
      
      
      Field and Outreach Experience
      
      June - July 2019 Herptile Population Monitoring Volunteer University of California, Santa Cruz Fort Ord Natural Reserve (Marina, CA)
      
      • Surveyed and monitored Blainville’s horned lizard populations by catching and PIT tagging individuals
      • Collected data using field measurement equipment to capture parameters such as weight & snout-vent length
      • Informed the dissertation of a Ph.D. student quantifying temporal differences in horned lizard population over time
      
      March - May 2019 Dungeness Crab Population Project Volunteer California State University, Monterey Bay (Seaside, CA)
      
      • Collected megalopa crab population data for a California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW) project aiming to inform Dungeness crab fisheries on local populations
      • Gathered and stored megalopa crab samples once a week from a crab trap at the Moss Landing Marine Labs boat dock
      • Organized and maintained crab sample counts and measurement data in the project notebook
      
      January - May 2018 Educational Outreach Volunteer Return of the Natives (Seaside, CA)
      
      • Co-taught an environmental education program for elementary classes at local, low-income schools
      • Prepared and organized lecture material for environmental science presentations adequate for 10-12-year olds. Topics included photosynthesis, plastics, and climate change
      • Assisted in organizing multiple beach planting community events with the goal of reintroducing 200+ native plants across ~5 species back to vulnerable dune ecosystems
      
      
      Skills and certifications
      Computer: R, GitHub, Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint), Google Suite
      Language: Bilingual (Spanish), public speaking, problem resolution, team building
      Certifications: CITI Responsible Research & Conduct, Trimble GPS
